Remember, transitioning careers is a journey. It requires time, continuous learning, and networking. But with your nursing skills and the growing intersection of healthcare and tech, you're well-prepared to embark on this exciting career change. Best of luck!

As for companies to consider when making this transition, here are ten options: Cerner, Epic Systems, Medtronic, Philips Healthcare, GE Healthcare, Allscripts, McKesson, Siemens Healthineers, Athenahealth, and Baxter International.
Projects: Propose improvements to the patient experience in your current job, volunteer to help a telehealth platform optimize their patient experience, take a course on UX or customer experience.
Patient Experience Manager: Oversee and improve patients' experience with healthcare tech platforms.Skills: Clinical knowledge, empathy, communication, project management.
Projects: Take an online course in data science, work on a project involving public health data and present your findings, contribute to open-source data science projects related to healthcare.
Healthcare Data Scientist: Use data to derive insights and improve healthcare outcomes.Skills: Clinical knowledge, data analysis, programming (e.g., Python, R), statistical knowledge.

Projects: Analyze and document a specific clinical process in your current job and propose tech-based improvements, take courses in data analytics and health informatics, volunteer to help a local clinic optimize their systems with tech solutions.

Clinical Systems Analyst: Use your nursing experience to analyze healthcare systems and processes, improving patient care through tech interventions.Skills: Clinical knowledge, analytical thinking, technical skills, problem-solving.

Projects: Volunteer to provide health education or consulting through a telehealth platform, create a guide for patients to navigate telehealth services, develop a proposal to enhance a telehealth service.
Telehealth Nurse Consultant: Provide healthcare consultation and support via telehealth platforms.Skills: Clinical knowledge, communication, empathy, problem-solving, tech-savviness.

Projects: Develop a proposal for a new tech product or feature, create a case study analyzing the success or failure of a health tech product, take a product management course and partake in related projects.

Healthtech Product Manager: Oversee the development of healthtech products, utilizing your clinical knowledge to create products that meet market demands.Skills: Clinical knowledge, leadership, market research, communication, problem-solving.
Projects: Participate in a sales or negotiation course or simulation, volunteer to fundraise for a non-profit, create a sales and marketing strategy for a hypothetical medical product.
Medical Device Sales Representative: Leverage your nursing knowledge to sell medical tech products to healthcare providers.Skills: Clinical knowledge, communication, sales, relationship building.
Projects: Develop a mock project to improve a healthcare process using technology, take a course on health informatics, analyze a public health data set and present your findings.
Clinical Informatics Specialist: Enhance healthcare delivery by working with healthcare data and technology.Skills: Clinical knowledge, data analysis, technical skills, problem-solving.
Projects: Launch a blog or YouTube channel on healthcare technology, create a case study evaluating a healthcare tech product, volunteer to help a health clinic or non-profit with their IT needs.

Healthcare IT Consultant: Use your nursing background to guide tech firms on designing, developing, and implementing healthcare systems.Skills: Clinical knowledge, IT skills, problem-solving, communication, project management.
Once you've defined your SME and transferable skills, it's time to explore career paths that leverage these abilities. Here are some tech roles that are particularly suitable for nurses:

Transferable skills are abilities that can seamlessly transition from one job to another. As a nurse, you've likely developed critical skills such as problem-solving, effective communication, teamwork, decision-making, empathy, and the ability to work under pressure.

Your SME stems from the vast healthcare knowledge you've accumulated throughout your nursing career. This includes an in-depth understanding of healthcare systems, patient care, clinical practices, and regulatory guidelines.

Before we dive in, it's crucial to identify your unique value proposition, summarizing your strongest professional skills and attributes. Your skills can be categorized into two groups: Subject Matter Expertise (SME) and Transferable Skills.

If you're a registered nurse pondering a career change, I encourage you to consider a career in tech. Wondering how to make this transition? Check this thread for a comprehensive guide for nurses seeking to transition into the tech industry.

Seek a mentor for guidance. Internally or Externally

Align your salary demands with what the market dictates, not merely your self-worth. Highlight the market's potential offer for your expertise. It's similar to how the Raptors secured FVV, recognizing that another team would've made the move if they hadn't.

Post-interview, be sure to inquire about the forthcoming steps and decision-making timeline. For roles you're particularly excited about and where the interview went smoothly, a follow-up in a few weeks to convey your eagerness and prompt readiness can be beneficial.

Some interviewers take pleasure in exerting their control, making the experience tense for candidates. Ignore them! Turning the situation around can be quite entertaining. Remember, the interview is just as much for you to discover the right position as it is for them

Take actionable steps by networking, attending industry events, and seeking mentorship to bridge the gap between your current skills and your desired career path.

The secret to pivoting careers – storytelling. Find the point of connection between your current job and the one you want. Learn how to speak the language of that job by speaking to other people in that role and find that point of connection to emphasize.

Implement a 'Mental Simulation' as part of your pre-interview routine. Picture the complete interview journey, from the initial handshake to the composed handling of tough questions. This visualization strategy can lessen anxiety and elevate your performance during the interview.

Interviewers appreciate when candidates bring up insights on the company's policies, history, or culture, showing they've researched well. Checking out the company's and competitors' websites, along with employee reviews, is a smart strategy.

Create your own networking opportunities by organizing events. Use tools like Twitter Spaces or Clubhouse for discussions on topics you're passionate about, helping you to stand out.

In interviews, present the event briefly. Open up about your personal response to connect with the interviewer. Clearly state the unique lesson you took away, and describe how you've already applied this wisdom or intend to, demonstrating personal growth and foresight

Your past doesn’t have to equal your future unless you choose to live there. Actively shape your future by setting new goals, acquiring new skills, and leveraging your past experiences as valuable lessons.

Confidence is essential. Discuss your achievements, problem-solving abilities, and past team collaborations. For management interviews, provide a detailed example of how you successfully led a team to achieve a challenging objective.

Quick tip: Don't hesitate to switch jobs for better prospects. Underappreciated? Consider a change. Unhealthy work culture? Time to go. No advancement? Look elsewhere. Snubbed for advancement? Job hop.
Always be authentic. Genuine rapport is crucial when meeting new people; an earnest connection outshines a feigned one. Remember, people can discern sincerity and will gravitate towards it.
Focus on making one or two connections per networking event, and be strategic about which events you go to. No need to go to all the socials, just the ones that you think will be beneficial.

If you have an interview with a Co-Founder or CEO coming up. Make sure you realize this. 

They will be far removed from your Day to Day, but they want to see if you care about the business. Ask questions about the business, its direction, comps and what they see for the future

Engage in 'Contextual Learning' by studying case studies from the company's industry. Mentioning these scenarios during your interview can showcase your analytical strengths and in-depth industry knowledge, illustrating your readiness to contribute meaningfully.
